dimension_explanations.alignment: This cause is categorized under domestic poverty and criminal justice reform, which may represent a lower donor fit for those prioritizing international humanitarian aid [1]. As a sadaqah-eligible organization, it provides a pathway for general charitable giving toward systemic legal equity [3].

While its capacity-building model makes direct cost-per-beneficiary metrics difficult to calculate, its 90.2% program expense Ratio indicates a strong commitment to its revolving fund and public education programs [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Chicago Community Bond Fund provides critical financial assistance to individuals in Cook County by paying bond for those whose communities cannot afford the cost of pretrial release.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 90.2%, ensuring the vast majority of funds go directly to services [1].
Exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.07 per $1 raised [1].
Strong liquidity with 47.4 months of working capital available to sustain operations [1].
baseline_narrative.summary: The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) operates a revolving fund to secure the release of individuals in Cook County, Illinois, while engaging in public education regarding the bond system [1][3]. In the most recent fiscal year, the organization reported a Total Revenue of $751,883 to support its mission of ending money bond and pretrial detention [2].

impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that paying bond effectively leads to better legal outcomes for the individuals served.

strengths.detail: The organization directs a <cite id="9">program expense ratio of 90.2%</cite> toward its mission, ensuring maximum utility of donor funds.
CCBF maintains a <cite id="10">96/100 accountability score</cite> and a <cite id="11">perfect 100/100 culture and leadership score</cite>.
The charity possesses <cite id="12">47.4 months of working capital</cite>, providing extreme stability for its revolving fund operations.

strengths_deep_dive: The Chicago Community Bond Fund demonstrates a highly efficient financial model where <cite id="13">fundraising efficiency is $0.07 per $1 raised</cite>, significantly outperforming industry benchmarks. This lean operation is supported by an <cite id="14">independent board of 8 members</cite>, ensuring 90.2% independent oversight of the organization's strategic direction. Furthermore, the organization's <cite id="15">documented theory of change</cite> provides a clear roadmap for how its revolving fund and advocacy efforts lead to systemic legal reform.
rich_narrative.summary: The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) is a specialized legal advocacy organization dedicated to <cite id="1">ending money bond and pretrial detention</cite> in Cook County, Illinois. By operating a <cite id="2">revolving fund to pay bond</cite> for individuals who cannot afford the cost of pretrial release, CCBF provides immediate relief while simultaneously engaging in <cite id="3">public education and organizing</cite> to transform the criminal legal system. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported <cite id="4">total revenue of $751,883</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="5">$730,862 in public contributions</cite>. Despite its modest revenue size, the organization maintains a significant financial footprint with <cite id="6">total assets of $7,164,767</cite>, largely held within its revolving fund to ensure long-term sustainability of its bond-paying capacity. The charity holds a <cite id="7">Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite> and has earned a <cite id="8">96/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting high standards of accountability and organizational culture.
